Here is a dog dressed as Paddington Bear and it’s wonderful

Bertram The Pomeranian pulls the look off with aplomb.
















Bertram The Pomeranian as Paddington Bear (Kathy Grayson)












August 7 2018






0
 Comments





Here is a dog dressed as Paddington Bear and it’s wonderful

Belfast

A dog has already won Halloween 2018 after his specially-made costume arrived early and he tried it on.

https://www.belfasttelegraph/news/viral/here-is-a-dog-dressed-as-paddington-bear-and-its-wonderful-37192599.html

https://www.belfasttelegraph/news/viral/article37192594.ece/e7461/AUTOCROP/h342/bpanews_25664b9d-f201-4a6f-80ae-474802feecbf_1





Email







A dog has already won Halloween 2018 after his specially-made costume arrived early and he tried it on.







(adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({})


Bertram The Pomeranian looks so good as Paddington Bear – complete with his red hat and blue coat – that it’s hard to remember he’s a dog. 

Bertie’s picture was shared on his own Instagram account by his owner Kathy Grayson and it was later shared and reposted on other social media accounts with messages of joy at discovering his picture. 


 
 


 
 
So my Halloween costume arrived a few months early 😬 tho makes a pretty fun fetch toy for now #chocolatepom #pomeranian

 
A post shared by 
 Bertram The Pomeranian
 (@bertiebertthepom) on 
Aug 4, 2018 at 2:30pm PDT




He lives in New York after being rehomed from a shelter in Oklahoma. He was originally called Jasper, but Kathy, who owns an art gallery, opted to rename him in honour of Bertie Wooster from PG Wodehouse’s Jeeves And Wooster novels. 

“I called him ‘Puppy Bear’ for months until I settled on a name, Bertie,” Kathy told the Press Association.

“By the time his adult fur grew in and he was fully grown, it was obvious that Bertie was the cutest guy in the world. People would stop us on the street all the time, and in NYC people usually don’t do that too much, so the power was real. 

“I had to create his own Instagram page for him because my art gallery page has to post paintings and sell art, and people just wanted to see Bert. 


 
 


 
 
Come see our summer art show. Pretty please? It’s called “EXTRA” #chocolatepom #pomeranian @theholenyc

 
A post shared by 
 Bertram The Pomeranian
 (@bertiebertthepom) on 
Jul 11, 2018 at 3:54pm PDT




“For these few years people would comment that Bert looks like Paddington, so after finally watching those movies I gave in and bought him a little Paddington Bear costume.”

Kathy purchased the outfit from a woman in the UK via Etsy.

“It fit him perfectly,” she added. “Now I just need a little suitcase and some galoshes and I will really have a bear on my hands here.”

Despite looking like the Marmalade-loving bear and the epitome of cuteness, Kathy says Bertie’s personality is his best attribute.

“He is so calm and chill he is just a funny, thoughtful, alert little friend. He doesn’t bite, almost never barks, he just stares and stares and smiles and romps.”


 
 


 
 
Sorry not sorry 😐 I just have too much joie de vivre to stay clean more than a few hours #chocolatepom #pomeranian

 
A post shared by 
 Bertram The Pomeranian
 (@bertiebertthepom) on 
Aug 3, 2018 at 5:03pm PDT




Bertie, now five, wears bow ties when he joins Kathy at work events in a nod to his namesake, enjoys swimming and playing in the dog pool and even eats cheese.

“At all times of day, having Bert with me is just a constant joy, I feel grateful every day, multiple times a day, to have this wonderful being here with me.”

Belfast

A large family pulled on their dinosaur costumes for an indoor dance party when it got too hot to play outside – and made a brilliant video in the process.

https://www.belfasttelegraph/news/viral/watch-this-family-enjoy-a-synchronised-dinosaur-dance-party-with-style-37192963.html

https://www.belfasttelegraph/news/viral/article37192961.ece/3b238/AUTOCROP/h342/bpanews_1a104f7c-2fba-4c54-b2b0-123f64972b2d_1





Email







A large family pulled on their dinosaur costumes for an indoor dance party when it got too hot to play outside – and made a brilliant video in the process.







(adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({})


The epic show, filmed for prosperity, includes synchronised dancing and air guitar – making it a thing of internet gold. 

The short clip shows parents Josh and Careese Wood in the full dino suits along with some of their nine children. Their youngest two – aged two and four – are at the front and dressed as mini dinosaurs.


 
 


 
 
Our answer to the question: “It’s too hot to play outside. What should we do today?”

 
A post shared by 
 Josh Wood
 (@joshwoodtx) on 
Jul 21, 2018 at 7:30pm PDT




“We’ve had so much fun with those dinosaur suits,” dad Josh told Press Association. “We’re probably the only family in America who had a dinosaur costume budget for fiscal year 2017.”

The family, from Texas, were trying to stay cool indoors last month when they hit upon the idea of an impromptu dance.

“It was 40C – which was too hot for the kids to play outside for more than a few minutes. 

“Since we’re big fans of spontaneous family dance parties, we thought it might be fun to put on our dinosaur suits and dance to the Walk The Dinosaur song. 

“My wife, Careese, had the brilliant idea to choreograph a short little dance. The kids loved it.” 

The family originally wore the suits when they went trick or treating in 2017. 

Josh said the cost was “money well spent” adding: “the ability to be ridiculous is one of the great joys of parenting”.

Josh blogs about family life at 
joshwoodtx
. His CraigList advert to sell his family’s old vehicle went viral for its honesty.

Lithuanian capital to launch G-spot tourism ad before papal visit

The campaign promoting Vilnius has drawn criticism from the Catholic Church.
















Pope Francis is scheduled to visit Lithuania in September (Gregorio Borgia/AP)












August 7 2018






0
 Comments





Lithuanian capital to launch G-spot tourism ad before papal visit

Belfast

Tourism chiefs in Lithuania’s capital are coming under fire for a sexualised advertising campaign to promote the city as the Pope prepares to visit next month.

https://www.belfasttelegraph/news/world-news/lithuanian-capital-to-launch-gspot-tourism-ad-before-papal-visit-37192902.html

https://www.belfasttelegraph/news/world-news/article37192900.ece/21361/AUTOCROP/h342/bpanews_4aaf9012-cf90-4125-b0da-6fe135df2cf9_1





Email







Tourism chiefs in Lithuania’s capital are coming under fire for a sexualised advertising campaign to promote the city as the Pope prepares to visit next month.







(adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({})


The campaign features a woman lying on what looks like a bed sheet printed with a map of Europe. Her hand grips Lithuania in a way that suggests sexual pleasure. 

The text above her reads: “Vilnius, the G-spot of Europe. Nobody knows where it is, but when you find it, it’s amazing.”

The campaign has been criticised by the Catholic Church and comes as Pope Francis prepares to visit the country next month. 


So apparently, the latest advertising campaign for the city of Vilnius was inspired by German doctor Ernst Gräfenberg, of g-spot fame. (And if you don't know where Vilnius is, well...) 

(via 
@eurotopics
) 
pic.twitter/aTgE5FJsfj

— Katrin Scheib (@kscheib) 
August 7, 2018




Lithuanian Prime Minister Saulius Skvernelis said he does not find the campaign, set to be launched on Thursday in London and Berlin, offensive to standards of public decency, but acknowledged its timing was “rather weird”.

“I think it’s a strange advertising choice, but I believe it does not cross the line in a democratic country,” Mr Skvernelis told Lithuanian public broadcaster LRT.

Francis’ September 22-25 tour of Baltic countries is supposed to start in Lithuania, where Catholics are the religious majority.

“As to the timing, we are speaking about a very important visit to Lithuania,” the prime minister added, referring to the pope’s visit. “So perhaps these steps should have been co-ordinated, but that’s the decision of Vilnius.”

Lithuanian priests expressed concerns that the ad used “women’s sexuality for advertising” and gave “wrong ideas” about Vilnius, a city with a population of 540,000. The government earlier originally asked Vilnius officials to postpone the ad’s launch until after the papal visit.

Inga Romanovskiene, the manager of the Go Vilnius tourism agency behind the campaign, called the pope’s visit “a very important event.”

Vilnius faces “a very high level of competition from other European cities” when it comes to marketing, and those who presented the campaign had “an extremely engaging idea to drive interest in the city”, she said.
